baseline_groups.claim_summary: The transition to coordinated Thursday price cycling in Perth retail gasoline (circa March 2010) increased retail margins by approximately 5.3 cents per liter (cpl), estimated via panel fixed effects with station FE on major-brand stations.
baseline_groups.notes: Four baseline variants represent the same core claim with progressively richer controls: (1) station FE only (coef=5.31), (2) + DOW dummies (5.35), (3) + wholesale cost change (5.31), (4) + DOW + cost (5.35). All produce nearly identical estimates. The primary baseline (station FE only, coef=5.31, SE=0.076, p<0.001) is the paper's central formalized claim. The paper itself is primarily descriptive, documenting price coordination through figures rather than formal regression tables; these specifications formalize the paper's central empirical assertion.

global_notes: Paper is 'Learning to Coordinate: A Study in Retail Gasoline' by Byrne & de Roos (AER). The paper studies tacit collusion and price coordination in the Perth retail gasoline market, documenting how BP led a transition from irregular to coordinated weekly Thursday price cycles around March 2010. The specification search formalizes the paper's central empirical claim as a panel regression of retail margins on a post-coordination dummy with station fixed effects. There are 70 total specifications. The paper is fundamentally a before/after comparison with no untreated control group -- the post_coord dummy is a pure time variable, so month FE would absorb the treatment. Year FE can be included (reducing the estimate to ~4.66 cpl). Placebo tests (fake treatment dates 2005-2008 in the pre-period) produce positive and significant effects (1.2-2.1 cpl), suggesting a pre-existing upward trend in margins that accounts for some fraction of the baseline 5.3 cpl estimate. Quantile regressions are non-core because they use a fundamentally different estimator (unconditional quantile regression without station FE). The 4 baseline specs are extremely close in coefficient value (5.31-5.35 cpl) and are treated as a single baseline group.
